productText:
000
FXUS61 KOKX 130251
AFDOKX

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service New York NY
951 PM EST Sun Feb 12 2023

.SYNOPSIS...
Low pressure passes by to our south tonight into Monday. A weak
cold front then moves through Monday night. High pressure builds
back in for Tuesday and slides offshore Wednesday. A warm front
lifts through the region on Thursday, with the associated cold 
front following on Friday. High pressure returns for next 
weekend.

&&

.NEAR TERM /UNTIL 6 AM MONDAY MORNING/...
Cloudy tonight with low pressure approaching from the south. 
Rain will continue to overspread srn and ern areas. Thermal 
profiles support rain. The only outside chance of a wintry mix 
would be over interior SE CT where wet-bulbing could cause the 
thermal profile to cool, but overall chances here for any precip
are low as there's plenty of dry low to mid level air to 
overcome. Rain amounts will be light as the area will be on the 
northern periphery of the rain shield.

&&

.SHORT TERM /6 AM MONDAY MORNING THROUGH MONDAY NIGHT/...
The center of the the storm will be passing SE of the 40N/70W 
benchmark Monday morning. The back edge of the rain shield will be 
exiting east probably before daybreak, so only low chances of rain 
early on for the Twin Forks/New London County area. Clearing skies 
otherwise, with high temperatures around 10 degrees above normal.

A trough aloft shifts through the region during Monday night with a 
surface cold front or trough shifting through. Moisture is limited, 
so will go with a dry passage in the forecast. It'll turn breezy 
behind the front late at night, helping to produce wind chills 
mostly in the mid 20s to lower 30s.

&&

.LONG TERM /TUESDAY THROUGH SUNDAY/...
A quick moving trough over New England early Tuesday swings offshore 
early Tuesday, with ridging developing across the Eastern US into 
midweek. At the surface, high pressure quickly moves overhead on 
Tuesday, sliding offshore Tuesday night and setting up return 
southerly flow midweek.

A storm system cutting through the Upper Midwest passes well to the 
north on Wednesday as ridging continues to build aloft. A weak warm 
front lifts through on Wednesday, and a 50 kt LLJ at 925 mb may 
allow a few southerly wind gusts around 30 mph to mix down to the 
surface. Moisture is limited and expect conditions to remain dry, 
though skies may go overcast for a period with a high cloud deck 
overhead.

850 mb temperature anomalies climb to +10C to +15C Wednesday and 
Thursday with a mild SW flow. Went with a blend of NBM 50% and 75% 
percentiles for highs on Thursday given the potential to overachieve 
with 12Z run of NAEFS, forecast temperatures +2 to +3 standard 
deviations above normal during this time. This yields forecast highs 
close to 60 both days, or about 20 degrees above climatology.

Pressure gradient begins to tighten on Thursday ahead of the next 
approaching storm system from the west. Timing has moved up a bit 
from previous cycles, with the warm front now progged to lift 
through the region Thursday, and the attendant cold front on Friday.
Temperatures may hold steady, or even rise, overnight into Friday as 
the region lies in the warm sector of the system. Scattered rain 
showers are likely along the warm front on Thursday, with another 
period of rain Thursday night into Friday ahead of the cold front. 
Several weak waves of low pressure may also attempt to slide along 
the front as well, enhancing the available moisture content. Could 
see some brief heavy rain with the cold front early Friday and may 
have to watch for any potential stronger wind gusts than forecast 
being brought down by the frontal showers. Showalter indices stay 
positive enough to preclude mention of any thunder.

Behind the frontal passage, winds veer northwest and colder air 
advects in and brings a brief return to temperatures more 
appropriate for mid-February. Depending on the timing of the cold 
front, temperatures may fall through the afternoon Friday, with the 
entire region below freezing Friday night and Saturday morning. 
Ensembles continue to prog the incoming air mass as seasonable, 
rather than any anomalously cool or sustained cold. With the 
exceptions noted above, stuck close to national blended guidance for 
this update.

&&

.AVIATION /03Z MONDAY THROUGH FRIDAY/...
An area of low pressure passes south of the terminals tonight 
into early Monday.

Mainly VFR through the TAF period. 

Light rain will impact srn and ern arpts thru around 6Z. There
could be a few MVFR pockets, but the prob was too low to include
in the TAFs.

Once the low passes east of the area Monday morning, skies are
expected to clear for Monday afternoon. 

With the low passing nearby, winds will gradually shift through much 
of the entire period. E winds become more northerly tngt, and 
eventually during the day Monday, northwesterly and westerly. 
Speeds will generally remain at or below 10kt, except further 
west where speeds could reach 12 or 13kt. KGON may even see some
gusts late in the TAF period. 

 ...NY Metro (KEWR/KLGA/KJFK/KTEB) TAF Uncertainty...

Some periods of MVFR possible thru about 6Z.

OUTLOOK FOR 00Z TUESDAY THROUGH FRIDAY...

Monday Night...VFR. NW winds 15-20 kt. 

Tuesday...VFR. NW winds gusts near 20 kt, mainly in the morning.
Gusts diminish late afternoon into the night.

Wednesday...Mainly VFR. S-SW winds 15-20 kt with gusts near 
25-30 kt.

Thursday...MVFR and rain showers possible, mainly afternoon 
into the evening. SW winds 5-10G15-20

Thursday night/Friday...Rain showers become likely and 
continuing into Friday morning. MVFR or lower likely. 
SW gusts 25-30 kt Friday morning.

Detailed information, including hourly TAF wind component forecasts, 
can be found at: https:/www.weather.gov/zny/n90

&&

.MARINE...
A low pressure system sliding to the south of the area tonight into 
Monday will bring SCA conditions to the ocean waters tonight through 
Monday night. A few gusts to 25 kt will be possible tonight over the 
easternmost portion of LI Sound.

A few 25 kt gusts are possible Tuesday morning before lowering 
below SCA criteria, though ocean seas may linger around 4 to 6 
ft into Tuesday afternoon.

SCA conditions likely return to all waters Wednesday with southerly 
winds gusting 25 to 30 kt during the afternoon. The flow lightens 
Wednesday night, before increasing once again late Thursday. A 
period of gales is possible, particularly on the ocean, Thursday 
night through Friday night with a frontal system moving through the 
waters. Seas on the ocean likely peak at 7 to 10 ft during this time.

Winds decrease on all waters Saturday, but seas may continue 
to linger around 5 ft on the ocean.

&&

.HYDROLOGY...
No hydrologic impacts are expected through the middle of the
week. Brief heavy rain possible early Friday but with fast 
movement. At this moment, not expecting any significant 
hydrologic issues.

&&

.OKX WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...
CT...None.
NY...None.
NJ...None.
MARINE...Small Craft Advisory until 5 AM EST Tuesday for ANZ350-353-355.

&&

$$
